{{Refimprove|date=July 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1592|literature}}
<!-- formerly (18apr07): ''See also:'' [[1591 in literature]], [[1592|other events of 1592]], [[1593 in literature]], [[list of years in literature]]. --> This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1592'''.
==Events== *[[February 5]]–[[February 7|7]] – ''Ulysses Redux'', a Latin play by [[William Gager]], is staged by members of [[Christ Church, Oxford]]. Two days later, they revive Gager's [[1583 in literature|1583]] Latin play ''Rivales'' (now lost). *[[February 26]] – First definitely recorded performance of [[Christopher Marlowe]]'s ''[[The Jew of Malta]]'', by [[Lord Strange's Men]] in London. *[[June 23]] – The London theatres are closed, remaining so for about 16 months due to an epidemic of [[bubonic plague]] (apart from a brief spell around January 1593). *[[September 3]] – English writer [[Robert Greene (dramatist)|Robert Greene]] dies in London of a "banquet of Rhenish wine and pickled herring",<ref>According to [[Thomas Nashe]].</ref> having apparently completed ''[[Greene's Groats-Worth of Wit]]'' (published soon after) including a reference to "an upstart Crow, beautified with our feathers", taken to be the first published (critical) reference to [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] as a playwright. *[[September 26]] – ''Rivales'' is performed again by members of Christ Church, with Queen [[Elizabeth I of England]] in the audience, during her second visit to the University of Oxford. *October–December – [[Pembroke's Men]], an English [[playing company]], is known to be in existence, acting in [[Leicester]] and at Court in London. *[[Isaac Casaubon]] publishes his edition of [[Theophrastus]]'s ''Characteres'', setting him on a career as an editor. *Antonio Agustin's ''{{lang|it|Dialoghi intorno alle medaglie inscrittioni et attre antichità}}'' is published in Rome with [[woodcut]]s by [[Geronima Parasole]], making it the first known printed book with illustrations by a woman. *Approximate date of first printing of ''[[Journey to the West]]'' (attributed to [[Wu Cheng'en]]).<ref>{{cite book|editor=Yu, Anthony C.|title=The Journey to the West|volume=1|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=1977|page=14}}</ref>
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Blaise de Lasseran-Massencôme, seigneur de Montluc|Blaise de Montluc]] (posthumously) – ''{{lang|fr|Commentaires de Messire Blaise de Montluc}}'' *[[Robert Greene (dramatist)|Robert Greene]] **''The Black Books Messenger'' **''A Disputation Between a Hee Conny-Catcher and a Shee Conny-Catcher'' **''The Third and Last Part of Conycatching'' **''[[Greene's Groats-Worth of Wit|Greene's Groats-Worth of Wit, Bought with a Million of Repentance]]'' **''Greene's Vision, Written at the Instant of his Death'' **''Philomela'' **''A Quip for an Upstart Courtier'' *[[Richard Johnson (16th century)|Richard Johnson]] – ''[[Nine Worthies of London]]'' *[[Lucas Janszoon Waghenaer]] – ''Thresoor der Zeevaert'' (Treasure of navigation)
===Drama=== *Anonymous (variously attributed to [[Thomas Kyd]], [[William Shakespeare]] and/or [[Christopher Marlowe]]) – ''[[Arden of Faversham]]'' (published) *Anonymous – ''[[A Knack To Know A Knave|A Knack to Know a Knave]]'' *[[William Gager]] – ''Ulysses Redux'' ([[Latin]]) *[[Thomas Kyd]] – ''[[The Spanish Tragedy]]'' (undated first printing, almost certainly between October and December in this year; first performed around 1587; first recorded performance November in this year) *[[John Lyly]] – ''[[Gallathea]]'' and ''[[Midas (Lyly play)|Midas]]'' published *[[Christopher Marlowe]] – ''[[Edward II (play)|Edward II]]'' *[[Thomas Nashe]] – ''[[Summer's Last Will and Testament]]''
===Poetry=== *[[Henry Constable]] – ''Diana'' *[[Michael Drayton]] – ''The Shepherd's Garland'' *[[Gabriel Harvey]] – ''Foure Letters and certaine Sonnets''
==Births== *[[January 16]] (baptised) – [[Henry King (poet)|Henry King]], English poet and bishop (died [[1669 in literature|1669]]) *[[January 22]] – [[Pierre Gassendi]], French philosopher and scientist (died [[1655 in literature|1655]]) *[[March 28]] – [[John Amos Comenius]] (Jan Amos Komenský), Czech teacher and writer (died [[1670 in literature|1670]]) *[[April 4]] – [[Abraham Elzevir]], Dutch printer (died [[1652 in literature|1652]]) *[[May 8]] – [[Francis Quarles]], English poet (died [[1644 in literature|1644]]) *[[July 10]] – [[Pierre d'Hozier]], French historian (died [[1660 in literature|1660]]) *[[August 1]] – [[François le Métel de Boisrobert]], French poet (died [[1662 in literature|1662]])
==Deaths== *[[July 22]] – [[Ludwig Rabus]], German Lutheran theologian (born [[1523 in literature|1523]]) *[[September 3]] – [[Robert Greene (dramatist)|Robert Greene]], English writer (born [[1558 in literature|1558]]) *[[September 13]] – [[Michel de Montaigne]], French essayist (born [[1533 in literature|1533]]) *[[September 26]] ''(bur.)'' – [[Thomas Watson (poet)|Thomas Watson]], English lyric poet writing in English and Latin (born [[1555 in literature|1555]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Amadis Jamyn]], French poet (born [[1538 in literature|1538]])
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1592 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 16th century in literature]]

[[File:Goltz-Selfportrait.jpg|thumb|185px|Self-portrait; from the ''Neue Illustrirte Zeitung'' (1889)]] '''Alexander Demetrius Goltz''' (25 January 1857, [[Püspökladány]] - 14 May 1944, [[Vienna]]) was a Hungarian-born Austrian painter, illustrator and scenic designer.
== Biography == He was the son of a railway engineer and, after the age of two, grew up in Vienna. From 1874 to 1875, he studied with [[Otto Seitz]] at the [[Academy of Fine Arts, Munich]]. Then, for the next two years, he was a student of [[Anselm Feuerbach]] at the [[Academy of Fine Arts, Vienna]].<ref name="O">{{ÖBL|2|29||Goltz Alexander Demetrius|}}</ref> His first exhibition was in 1876 and he became a member of the [[Vienna Künstlerhaus]].
This was followed by several study trips, a stay in Munich from 1884 to 1888, and studies with [[Pierre Puvis de Chavannes]] in Paris. He finally returned to Vienna in 1892.<ref name="B">Reinhard Müller: [http://agso.uni-graz.at/marienthal/biografien/goltz_alexander_demetrius.htm ''Alexander Demetrius Goltz'']. In: ''Die Arbeitslosen von Marienthal'', Juni 2008; retrieved, 18 September 2011.</ref> Beginning as a history painter, he later turned to landscapes and portraits. From 1904 to 1907, he was in charge of the scenic equipment at the [[Burgtheater]], then held the same position at the [[Vienna State Opera]] from 1909 to 1910.<ref name="O" /> During this time, he painted the portraits of numerous performers; notably [[Josef Kainz]].
He was a member of the [[Hagenbund]] from 1900 to 1911 and served as its President for the year 1906/07. During the First World War, he served as a [[battle painter]] for the Imperial {{ill|Kriegspressequartier|de|k.u.k. Kriegspressequartier}} and worked at the fronts in Belgium, Russia, Italy, Serbia and Turkey. Most of these paintings are now on display at the [[Museum of Military History, Vienna|Museum of Military History]].
From 1925 to 1929, he was President of the Artists' Cooperative at the Künstlerhaus. He was married twice. His second wife (who he married in 1909) was the actress Mary Mell (1885-1954), sister of the writer, {{ill|Max Mell|de}}. In 1927, he became a citizen of Vienna and is buried at the [[Zentralfriedhof]].<ref name="B" />
==Selected paintings== <gallery mode="packed" heights=145> File:Alexander Demetrius Goltz - Die Besucherin 1919.jpg|The Visitor File:Goltz-Spring.jpg|Spring File:Alexander Demetrius Goltz Kainz als Torquato Tasso 1910.jpg|Josef Kainz as [[Torquato Tasso (play)|Torquato Tasso]] Alexander Demetrius Goltz - Mädchen mit Puppe.jpg|Girl with a Puppet </gallery>
== References == {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Josef Soyka: ''A. D. Goltz. Aus seinem Leben und Schaffen''. Eckart-Verlag, Vienna 1927.
== External links == {{Commonscat|Alexander Demetrius Goltz}} *[http://www.artnet.com/artists/alexander-demetrius-goltz/past-auction-results ArtNet: More works by Goltz.] *{{ANNO|wrb|30|01|1927|09|Alexander D. Goltz Kollektivausstellung im Künstlerhaus Jänner – Februar 1927}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Goltz, Alexander Demetrius}} [[Category:1857 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century Austrian painters]] [[Category:20th-century Austrian painters]] [[Category:Austrian portrait painters]] [[Category:Austrian illustrators]] [[Category:Austrian scenic designers]] [[Category:Academy of Fine Arts Vienna alumni]] [[Category:Military art]] [[Category:People from Püspökladány]] [[Category:Austrian people of Hungarian descent]]

[[File:The Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay.jpg|right|thumb|The [[Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay]], Singapore.]] [[File:Appletonperformingartscenter.jpg|right|thumb|The [[Fox Cities Performing Arts Center]], Appleton, Wisconsin, USA.]] [[File:KimmelCenterInteriorHDR.jpg|right|thumb|The [[Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts]], Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA.]]'''Artec Consultants Inc''', is an acoustics design and theater planning firm located in New York City. The company was founded by [[Russell Johnson (acoustician)|Frederick Russell Johnson]] in 1970. In 2013, Artec was integrated into the acoustic design and theatre consulting practice Arup.
Artec has done the acoustics design and theatre planning for over 140 projects worldwide including the [[Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay]], [[Salle Pleyel]] renovation in [[Paris, France]], the [[Mariinsky Theatre Second Stage|Mariinsky II Opera House]] Basic Design for [[Valery Gergiev]], [[Kravis Center for the Performing Arts]], [[Jazz at Lincoln Center]], [[New Jersey Performing Arts Center]], [[Pikes Peak Center]], the [[Montreal Symphony House]], [[Centre in the Square]], [[Chan Centre for the Performing Arts]] and acoustical upgrade of the [[Roy Thomson Hall]].<ref name="toronto1">{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.com/article/698529--littler-a-sounder-structure-for-a-symphony |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130204210152/http://www.toronto.com/article/698529--littler-a-sounder-structure-for-a-symphony |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-04 |title=Littler: A sounder structure for a symphony - Music |publisher=Toronto.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-23 }}</ref>
The New York firm has been referred to as the field-leader in acoustic design<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/classical/features/classical-music-venues-not-for-the-fainthearted-2036136.html |title=Classical music venues: Not for the faint-hearted - Features, Classical |publisher=The Independent |date=2010-07-27 |accessdate=2011-10-23 |location=London}}</ref> and [[Time Magazine]] called their design of the Esplanade complex in Singapore "one of the best anywhere".<ref>{{cite news|last=James |first=Jamie |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,658369,00.html |title=Asia: Classical music's new superpower |publisher=TIME |date=2004-06-28 |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref>
==History== Artec was founded by [[Russell Johnson (acoustician)|Russell Johnson]].
Over the years, Artec became one of the most sought after acoustical consulting firms because of their unique movable and automatic technology that helped revolutionize the field. Their design enable through movable overhead canopies, retractable draperies and associated features, the adjustment of the acoustical environment to meet the needs of different kinds of music that could suit different performances or groups. The reflectors combined with a traditional shoebox shape design are consider trademarks of Artec.<ref>{{cite web|author=ARTHUR KAPTAINIS |url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/todays-paper/Concert+hall+architect+open+minded/5348881/story.html |title=Concert hall architect is open minded |publisher=Montrealgazette.com |date=2011-09-03 |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref>
The firm has collaborated on many projects with other architects including [[Cesar Pelli]], [[Jean Nouvel]], [[I.M. Pei]], [[Moshe Safdie]], [[Barton Myers]], [[Bing Thom]], [[Michael Wilford]], [[Eberhard Zeidler]], Fred Lebensold, [[James Stirling (architect)|Sir James Stirling]], [[Robert Venturi]], and [[Rafael Viñoly]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/11d5818a-db1c-11dc-9fdd-0000779fd2ac.html#axzz1ZFby5rCF |title=/ Arts - American Composers Festival; Orange County, California |publisher=Ft.com |date=2008-02-14 |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref>
After Johnson's death in 2007, the company was managed by partners and associates until integation with Arup in 2013.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russelljohnsonlegacy.com/russell_johnson_biography.html |title=Russell Johnson Biography |publisher=Russelljohnsonlegacy.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/9efbcdb6-70fd-11da-89d3-0000779e2340.html#axzz1ZFby5rCF |title=/ Arts - Acoustics first, then architecture |publisher=Ft.com |date=2005-12-20 |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/9f03eea6-b198-11db-b901-0000779e2340,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F9f03eea6-b198-11db-b901-0000779e2340.html&_i_referer=http%3A%2F%2Fsearch.ft.com%2Fsearch%3FqueryText%3DRussell%2BJohnson%26ftsearchType%3Dtype_news#axzz1ZFby5rCF |title=/ Media - Miami centre stage |publisher=Ft.com |date=2007-02-01 |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/a9c825e6-678c-11dc-9443-0000779fd2ac.html#axzz1ZFby5rCF |title=/ Life & Arts - History and its recurring themes |publisher=Ft.com |date=2007-09-20 |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_7161/is_201107/ai_n57807481/pg_2/ |title=IN CELEBRATION OF C.B. FISK INC. FIFTY YEARS OF INNOVATION, COLLABORATION, AND EDUCATION - page 2 | American Organist, The |publisher=Findarticles.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-23 }} {{Dead link|date=December 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/feb/13/entertainment/ca-artsnotes13.1 |title=Problems in doing volume business - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=2005-02-13 |accessdate=2011-10-23 |first=Mike |last=Boehm}}</ref>
===Public Attention===
In 2009, as a guest speaker and representative of Artec, Nakajima was invited to the [[Hong Kong Design Centre]] for its [[Business of Design Week]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bodw.com/2009/eng/speakers.php?all=yes |title=BODW 2009 |publisher=Bodw.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309014157/http://www.bodw.com/2009/eng/speakers.php?all=yes |archivedate=2012-03-09 }}</ref> He also spoke at the designer event LIVE! Singapore 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.live-singapore.com.sg/enews/2011-edm5/ |title=LIVE! Singapore |publisher=LIVE! Singapore |date=2011-03-15 |accessdate=2011-10-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513015010/http://www.live-singapore.com.sg/enews/2011-edm5/ |archivedate=2011-05-13 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
==External links== * [http://www.artecconsultants.com Artec Consultants]

page.title: Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue |name = Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance |image = BAAD!.jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = View of Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance from the street. |address = 2474 [[Westchester Square, Bronx|Westchester Avenue]]{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/listings/attraction/bronx-academy-arts-dance/|title=Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance - Performing Arts Venues - New York Magazine|publisher=nymag.com|accessdate=2016-06-01}} |city = [[The Bronx]], [[New York City]] |country = {{USA}} |designation = |latitude = |longitude = |architect = [[Leopold Eidlitz]]
[[Cyrus L. W. Eidlitz]] |owner = |capacity = 70 |type = [[Performing arts center]] |opened = 1998 |yearsactive = 1998 - present |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = '''BAAD!''' |production = |currentuse = |website = http://www.baadbronx.org/ }} '''Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance''', also referred to as '''BAAD!''', is a New York performing and visual art workshop space and performance venue located in [[The Bronx]].{{cite web|url=http://nyc.spacefinder.org/organizations/4107|title=BAAD ! the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance - SpaceFinder NYC|publisher=nyc.spacefinder.org|accessdate=2016-06-01}} The Academy is home to the Arthur Aviles Typical Theatre and The Bronx Dance Coalition. == History == The Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance was co-founded in 1998 by [[Arthur Aviles]], dancer and choreographer who performed with the [[Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company]], and Charles Rice-Gonzales, a writer, activist, and publicist.{{cite web|url=http://nycartscoalition.org/|title=NYC Arts Coalition|publisher=nycartscoalition.org|accessdate=2016-06-01}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/bronx/dominican-dance-traditions-alive-special-performance-hostos-community-college-article-1.952236|title=Hostos features Dominican traditional dance - NY Daily News|publisher=nydailynews.com|accessdate=2016-06-01}} The Academy was first located in a community center before renting space in the historic [[American Bank Note Company Printing Plant]] in the [[Hunts Point, Bronx|Hunts Point]] neighborhood of the [[South Bronx]] and was home to the Arthur Aviles Typical Theatre, a contemporary dance company focusing on works exploring the margins of Latino and LGBTQ cultures.https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/28/nyregion/in-new-home-bronx-dance-academy-seeks-to-step-up-its-presence.html?_r=2 The programs at BAAD! were made up of dancers, LGBTQ visual artists, women, and artists of color.{{cite web|url=http://www.baadbronx.org/about.html|title=About|publisher=baadbronx.org|accessdate=2016-06-01}} Artists began presenting work in the space and hosting annual arts festivals such as ''BAAD! Ass Women'', ''Out Like That!'', ''The BlakTino Performance Series'', ''The Boogie Down Dance Series'', and the holiday play ''Los Nutcrackers: A Christmas Carajo''.http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/bronx/arts-festival-hunts-point-celebrates-women-film-dance-poetry-theater-self-defense-workshop-article-1.1037673 In 2010 a film event series, titled ''Get Tough! Get BAAD!'' focusing on gay-bashings in New York City, was added. ''Out Like That!'' is the Bronx's only festival celebrating works by lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender artists.{{cite web|url=http://www.nyc-arts.org/organizations/2181/bronx-academy-of-arts-and-dance|title=Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance - NYC-ARTS|publisher=nyc-arts.org|accessdate=2016-06-01}} In 2002 the Bronx Dance Coalition, which supports professional Bronx dance and published the ''Bronx Dance Magazine'',http://www.pepatian.org/public_html/pdf/back_issue_05.pdf was formed at the Academy. Later the Muse/Artist in Residency Project was started. After 14 years in the American Bank Note Company Building, the Academy was forced to leave due to increasing rent. In October 2013, the Academy relocated to a gothic revivalist chapel in the cemetery on the grounds of the historic [[St. Peter's Church, Chapel and Cemetery Complex|St. Peter's Episcopal Church]] in [[Westchester Square, Bronx|Westchester Square]].{{cite web|url=http://brie.hunter.cuny.edu/hpe/2013/10/28/legendary-dance-group-gone-from-banknote/|title=Hunts Point Express – Legendary dance group gone from BankNote|publisher=brie.hunter.cuny.edu|accessdate=2016-06-01}} The chapel that houses the Academy was made a [[List of New York City Designated Landmarks in The Bronx|New York City Landmark]] in 1976 and was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1998.http://npgallery.nps.gov/nrhp/Download?path=/natreg/docs/All_Data.html In 1999 [[The New York Times]] crowned BAAD! "a funky and welcoming performance space" and Theater Journal said, "they have created a space for art in an environment that seems antithetical to that act. The Academy received the Mayor's Art and Culture Award.{{cite web|url=http://www.harlemonestop.com/organization/1385/bronx-academy-of-arts-dance-baad|title=Bronx Academy of Arts & Dance (BAAD!), Other - Harlem One Stop|publisher=harlemonestop.com|accessdate=2016-06-01}} In 2017 they were one of 12 grantees to receive a grant from the Lincoln Center Cultural Innovation Fund and the [[Rockefeller Foundation]] in order to {{Cite web|url=http://www.lincolncenterculturalinnovationfund.org/|title=Lincoln Center Cultural Innovation Fund|website=Lincoln Center Cultural Innovation Fund|access-date=2017-11-07}} "increase arts access and participation in the diverse neighborhoods of the [[South Bronx]] and [[Central Brooklyn]]. {{Cite news|url=http://thebronxchronicle.com/2017/06/28/recipients-from-central-brooklyn-and-south-bronx-receive-support-for-innovative-community-based-cultural-programs/|title=Recipients From Central Brooklyn and South Bronx Receive Support For Innovative Community-Based Cultural Programs - The Bronx Chronicle|date=2017-06-28|work=The Bronx Chronicle|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}} The 60K grant will be used for the Transvisionaries:Live Performance Series, a monthly free performance series featuring trans and [[gender non-conforming]] artists or color, hosted at local cafes in the South Bronx. The goal being to increase access to performance outside the theater while bringing visibility to [[Transgender|trans people]]. == References == {{reflist}} {{Coord|40|50|18|N|73|50|40|W|display=title}} [[Category:1998 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:African-American arts organizations]] [[Category:Art galleries in the Bronx]] [[Category:Arts organizations based in New York City]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1998]] [[Category:Caribbean-American culture in New York City]] [[Category:Contemporary dance]] [[Category:Culture of the Bronx]] [[Category:Dance events]] [[Category:Dance festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Dance in New York City]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American organizations]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American culture in New York City]] [[Category:Landmarks in the Bronx]] [[Category:Leopold Eidlitz buildings]] [[Category:LGBT arts organizations]] [[Category:LGBT Hispanic and Latino American culture]] [[Category:Music venues in New York City]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in the Bronx]] [[Category:Performing arts centers in New York City]] [[Category:Theatres in the Bronx]] [[Category:Event venues on the National Register of Historic Places in New York City]] [[Category:Westchester Square, Bronx]]

revision.text:
'''''Chanson réaliste''''' ({{IPA-fr|ʃɑ̃sɔ̃ ʁealist}}, ''realist song'') refers to a style of music performed in [[France]] primarily from the 1880s until the end of [[World War II]].<ref name=VICTORY>Sweeney, Regina M. (2001). ''Singing Our Way to Victory: French Cultural Politics and Music During the Great War'', Wesleyan University Press. p. 23. {{ISBN|0-8195-6473-7}}.</ref><ref name=MONTREAL>Fagot, Sylvain & Uzel, Jean-Philippe (2006). ''Énonciation artistique et socialité: actes du colloque international de Montréal des 3 et 4 mars 2005'', L'Harmattan. pp. 200-203. {{ISBN|2-296-00176-9}}. (French text)</ref> Influenced by [[literary realism]] and the [[Naturalism (literature)|naturalist movements in literature]] and [[Naturalism (theatre)|theatre]], ''chanson réaliste'' dealt with the lives of [[Paris]]'s poor and working-class.<ref name=POPULAR>Frith, Simon (2004). ''Popular Music: Critical Concepts in Media and Cultural Studies'', Routledge. pp. 225-227. {{ISBN|0-415-29905-5}}.</ref><ref name=THEATRE>Schechter, Joel (2003). ''Popular Theatre: A Sourcebook'', Routledge. pp. 181-183. {{ISBN|0-415-25830-8}}</ref><ref name=SPHINX>Wilson, Elizabeth (1992). ''The Sphinx in the City: Urban Life, the Control of Disorder, and Women'', University of California Press. p. 62. {{ISBN|0-520-07864-0}}</ref>
''Chanson réaliste'' was a musical style that was mainly performed by women;<ref name=POPULAR/><ref name=CHANTEUSE>Conway, Kelly (2004). ''Chanteuse in the City: The Realist Singer in French Film''. University of California Press. p. 6. {{ISBN|0-520-24407-9}} </ref> some of the more commonly known performers of the genre include [[Édith Piaf]] and [[Fréhel]].
==Origins and influences==
''Chanson réaliste'' grew out of the [[Café-chantant|''cafés-concerts'']] and [[cabarets]] of the [[Montmartre]] district of [[Paris]] during the 1880s.<ref name=VICTORY/><ref name="SPHINX"/> Home to such theatrical landmarks as the [[Moulin Rouge]], and [[Le Chat Noir]], Montmartre became a centre for [[hedonism|hedonistic]] and brazen entertainment from the late 19th century to the early 20th century.<ref name=MUDD>Gendron, Bernard (2002). ''Between Montmartre and the Mudd Club: Popular Music and the Avant-garde'', University of Chicago Press. pp. 36 & 53. {{ISBN|0-226-28735-1}}.</ref>
Although the ''chanson réaliste'' was a musical genre dominated by female vocalists, one of its earliest performers—and credited by some as "the creator" or "the father" of genre<ref name=CHANTEUSE/><ref name=SATIE>Moore Whiting, Steven (1999). ''Satie the Bohemian: From Cabaret to Concert Hall'', Oxford University Press. p. 20. {{ISBN|0-19-816458-0}}</ref><ref name=GERMANY>Robb, David (2007). ''Protest Song in East and West Germany Since the 1960s'', Boydell & Brewer. p. 36. {{ISBN|1-57113-281-3}}.</ref>—was cabaret singer and comedian [[Aristide Bruant]]. Bruant began a career at [[Le Chat Noir]] in 1885 and his [[Vaudeville (song)|vaudeville]]-inspired mix of song, satire and entertainment became very popular with the [[bourgeoisie]] [[slum tourism|slumming]] in the poorer Montmartre district.<ref name=THEATRE/><ref name=GERMANY/><ref name=BOHEMIANS>Wilson, Elizabeth (2003). ''Bohemians: The Glamorous Outcasts'', Tauris Parke Paperbacks. p 224. {{ISBN|1-86064-782-0}}.</ref> His compositions were also different in that they included the everyday language and slang used by the commoners.<ref name=VICTORY/>
Borrowing elements of the ''[[comédie en vaudeville]]'', the ''chanteuses réalistes'' (realist singers [female]) often wore black dresses, red lipstick and white face makeup—their faces highlighted with stark lighting, set against a modest, almost bare backdrop—all done to draw audiences' attention to the singers' emotive facial expressions.<ref name=POPULAR/>
In contrast to the picturesque ''[[Chanson#Chansons today|chanson]]'' which was popular in [[Provisional Government of the French Republic|post-World War II France]]—with its songs of love, cobbled Parisian streets, and the sound of the accordion—the ''chanteuses réalistes'' sang songs of loss, hopelessness and abandonment;<ref name=POPULAR/> their songs dealt with life in the poorer Parisian [[faubourgs]], and the thugs, [[pimp]]s, [[prostitute]]s, and [[orphan]]s who called them home;<ref name=VICTORY/><ref name=POPULAR/> its themes of [[poverty]] and the [[Organized crime|criminal underworld]], as well as its sociopolitical commentary, were influenced by the works of such [[Literary realism|literary realists]] and [[Naturalism (literature)|naturalist]] writers as [[Émile Zola]], [[Jean Richepin]] and [[Paul Bourget]].<ref name=THEATRE/><ref name=BOHEMIANS/>
==The performers==
The ''chanson réaliste'' sentimentalised the plight of poor and dispossessed women, such as prostitutes, waitresses, failed singers in cheap bars, orphans, single mothers and the like. Some of the performers of the genre were also known to have lived the part—both Édith Piaf and Fréhel sang in the streets as children, were teenage mothers and lost their children very young—and many shortened their lives with [[Drug abuse|drugs]], [[Alcohol abuse|alcohol]] and [[illness]]: [[Yvonne George]] lived an excessive lifestyle and died at the age of 34; Fréhel became an [[alcoholism|alcoholic]] at an early age, attempted [[suicide]] at 19 and eventually died in poverty; Piaf suffered from [[Substance dependence|addictions]] to [[morphine]] and alcohol and died of [[cancer]].<ref name=POPULAR/><ref name=SPHINX/>
However, given the dramatic and melancholy aspects of ''chanson réaliste'', the withered and diseased aspect of their appearance became an integral part of the show.<ref name=POPULAR/> Piaf, for example, was known for her [[waif]]-like stage presence and became tightly identified with her role;<ref name=TECHNO>Cannon, Steve & Dauncey, Hugh (2003). ''Popular Music in France from Chanson to Techno: Culture, Identity, and Society'', Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. p. 30. {{ISBN|0-7546-0849-2}}.</ref> she was, however, critical of the style:<ref name=POPULAR/>
{{Quote|I don't like realist songs...For me they're vulgar tunes with blokes wearing cloth caps and girls plying their trade on the streets. I hate that. I like flowers and simple love stories, health, ''[[joie de vivre]]'' and Paris.|Édith Piaf|}}
Another common theme of the ''chanson réaliste'' was [[motherhood]], particularly the mother-son relationship; such songs were a speciality of the singer Berthe Sylva, whose songs dealt with such topics as dying mothers, mothers worrying about their sons at war, sons placing flowers on a mother's grave, and songs about the mundane experiences of a bored [[homemaker|housewife]].<ref name=POPULAR/>
Other women known for performing in the ''chanson réaliste'' style include: * [[Eugénie Buffet]] * [[Marie-Louise Damien|Damia]] * [[Marie Dubas]] * [[Lys Gauty]]
== See also == * [[Chanson]] * [[Belle Époque]] * [[Realism (theatre)|Realism in theatre]] * [[Realism (visual arts)|Realism in the visual arts]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chanson Realiste}} [[Category:French styles of music]] [[Category:Music in Paris]] [[Category:Realism (art movement)]] [[Category:Literary realism]]

'''Craftivism''' is a form of [[activism]], typically incorporating elements of [[anti-capitalism]], [[environmentalism]], solidarity, or [[third-wave feminism]], that is centered on practices of [[craft]] - or what can traditionally be referred to as "domestic arts". Craftivism includes, but is not limited to, various forms of needlework including yarn-bombing or cross-stitch. Craftivism is a social process of collective empowerment, action, expression and negotiation. In craftivism, engaging in the social, performative and critical discourse around the work is central to its production and dissemination.<ref>Carpenter, Ele. "Activist Tendencies in Craft". http://research.gold.ac.uk/3109/, 2010.</ref> Practitioners are known as '''craftivists'''.
== Background == The term '''craftivism''' was coined in 2003 by writer Betsy Greer in order to join the separate spheres of craft and activism.<ref>{{harvnb|Greer|2008|p=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Craftivism, Arnolfini, Bristol |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/reviews/craftivism-arnolfini-bristol-1855855.html |first=Charles |last=Darwent |date=3 January 2010 |location=London |work=The Independent}} </ref> Her favorite self-created definition of the term states, "craftivism is a way of looking at life where voicing opinions through creativity makes your voice stronger, your compassion deeper & your quest for justice more infinite"<ref>{{cite web |title=Crafting a Green World. What is Craftivism? Division over the Definition Explodes Etsy Team |url=http://craftingagreenworld.com/2009/04/04/what-is-craftivism-division-over-the-definition-explodes-an-etsy-team/ |work=Crafting a Green World |first=Julie |last=Finn |date=April 4, 2009}}</ref>
Although the term craftivism is a recent addition to crafting lexicon, the use of craft as a subversive tactic can be found throughout history. First, the word craft is often associated with trickery. To call someone crafty is to identify them as clever and cunning <ref>{{harvnb|Bratich|2006|p=29}}</ref> In Greek, one would say to "spin" a plot. Similarly, the French word for trick is tricoter, which means to tie or knot together.<ref>{{harvnb|Bratich|2006|p=30}}</ref> In the novel ''[[A Tale of Two Cities]]'', the character [[Madame Defarge]], a worker for the [[French Revolution]], secretly encodes the names of those soon to be executed in her knitting.
=== Feminism === Craftivism identifies strongly with feminist movements. Craftivism is often interpreted as having emerged from [[third-wave feminism]] but feminist activism and craft were unified beforehand.<ref name="academia.edu">{{cite journal|last1=Bratich|first1=Jack|last2=Bush|first2=Heidi|title=Fabricating Activism: Craft Work, Popular Culture, Gender|journal=Project Muse|date=2011|volume=22|issue=2|url=https://www.academia.edu/1117424/Fabricating_Activism_Craft-Work_Popular_Culture_Gender|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
Practices of craft or "domestic arts" have traditionally existed and been organized spatially within the private sphere. Therefore, the labor and production of craft was generally interpreted as unproductive female labor in the home, as it was never integrated into profit-making systems. Rather, it was [[marginalized]] and undervalued.<ref>{{harvnb|Bratich|2006|p=11}}</ref> As a result, women's significant and creative work in the private sphere—clothing the family, knitting blankets, weaving the loom—did not receive the same respect as male-dominated activity in the public realm. Furthermore, the patriarchy has been successful in claiming these domestic values for women and using it as a way to keep women in subservient roles.<ref name="Sabella">{{cite news |last=Sabella |first=Jennifer |date=May 12, 2008 |title= Craftivism: Is crafting the new activism? |work=The Columbia Chronicle |location=Chicago}}</ref> The rise of consumer-friendly crafts, including kits, transfers and readymade designs, has further diminished the status of craft and women's amateur practices.<ref>Fiona Hackley, "Quiet Activism and the New Amateur," Design and Culture, 5:2 (2013): 173.</ref> Women and craft have been excluded from the fine art world and as a result many women put their creativity towards craft practices. Craft was "a universal female art from transcending race, class, and national borders. Needlework is the one art in which women controlled the education of their daughters and the production of art, and were also the critics and audience."<ref name="Packer 2010"/> Although practices of craft were spatially organized within the private sphere, women occasionally would organize groups to engage in these practices collectively. In these craft circles or meet ups women would not only share patterns and skills but also engage in conversation about their lives in the private sphere. These groups of women would discuss their lives and personal struggles encountered as women. This type of group discussion is a form of activism rooted in [[Consciousness raising]] that was key to [[Second-wave feminism]]<ref name="academia.edu"/> as it helped to raise awareness about the types of oppression women were experiencing in their everyday lives.
The Anti Capitalist, Anti Sweatshop and DIY movements popularized practices of craft for activism. These movements influenced third-wave feminists to adopt a craftivism ethos. Most forms of craftivism identify strongly with [[third-wave feminism]]. Third-wave feminist crafters are attempting to subvert the association of craft with domesticity by embracing domestic arts while identifying as feminists who are making the choice to embrace this new domesticity. Third-wave feminists are reclaiming knitting, sewing, and other crafting activities traditionally feminized and associated with the private sphere. Through this reclamation, contemporary women aim to reconnect with the female-dominated art forms, to legitimatize the importance of undervalued craft, and to show that 21st century women have the privilege to express themselves through craft, with fewer constraints exercised by the patriarchy. This act of resistance and shattering of the public/private binary is expressed physically through public knitting and craft circles who take a private-sphere activity and insert themselves in the male-dominated spaces of the city<ref name="Robertson, Kirsty 2006">Robertson, Kirsty. 30 March 2006. How to Knit an Academic Paper. Queen's University.</ref> One example would be the [[Anarchist Knitting Mob]] who held a "Massive Knit" event in Washington Square Park to honour the death of activist and urbanist [[Jane Jacobs]].<ref>http://massiveknit.blogspot.com/</ref> Knitters decorated the trees, benches, and light posts with colourful yarn and unique patterns. [[Sarah Corbett]], founder of [[Craftivist_Collective|Craftivist Collective]], encourages craftivists to set up private and public what she coined 'stitch-in' workshops.<ref>[https://craftivist-collective.com/blog/2013/09/how-to-host-your-own-stitch-in/ ''How To Host Your Own Stitch-In''] Craftivist-Collective.com. Retrieved 28 August 2018</ref>
====Criticism==== Women’s craft has often been undervalued or ignored in the art world. Women’s craft is considered belonging to a lesser cultural sphere and categorized under such terms as ‘applied’, ‘decorative’ or ‘lesser’ than other art forms such as painting or sculpture.<ref name="Packer 2010">{{cite journal|last1=Packer|first1=Carolyn|title=The Evolution of Craft In Contemporary Feminist Art|journal=Scholarship Claremont|date=2010|url=http://scholarship.claremont.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1022&context=scripps_theses|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> This critique of women’s craft and craftivism as a ‘lesser’ art form has been contested within the discourse of feminism. Some Feminist Art discourse excludes craftivism. This feminist intervention into the art world perpetuates a hierarchy of art where craft is a lower art form. Some feminists deem craftivism as reinforcing domesticity and consider it a retrogression of the feminist cause rather than a subversive tactic.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Raven|first1=Charlotte|title=How the 'New Feminism' Went Wrong|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/mar/06/charlotte-raven-feminism-madonna-price|website=www.theguardian.com|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
=== Environmentalism === Craftivism is also centered on ideas of environmentalism and sustainability. When buying new materials, many craftivists choose organic fabrics and fairly traded products such as home-spun yarns. Yet, even more popular within the movement is the utilization of vintage, thrifted and repurposed goods in order to minimize waste and promote reuse. This display of resourcefulness acknowledges the finite resources on Earth, and the valorization of quality over quantity. Craftivist, Betsy Greer, is quoted saying, "While I think that crafting has become something fairly elite and cliquish in some areas, at its heart, it is very much made for individuals who value both their time and their money".<ref name="Sabella"/>
=== Anti-capitalism === Historically, craft was the pre-capitalist form of production, where each created item possessed a "use-value," a term comparing the usefulness of an item to the exchange equivalent.<ref>{{cite book |first=Vivienne |last=Brown |year=2009 |editor=Stephanie Taylor |editor2=Steve Hinchliffe |editor3=John Clarke |editor4=Simon Bromley |chapter=Rubbish society: affluence, waste and values |title=Making Social Lives |location=Milton Keynes |publisher=The Open University |page=122 |isbn=0749216417}}</ref> Now within a capitalist system of mass production, craft has become a commodity to be bought and sold for money, where it is now referred to as having an "exchange-value".<ref>{{harvnb|Bratich|2006|p=27}}</ref> Due to this movement from use-value to exchange-value, there is less emphasis on the time and skill expended to create an object, and more importance on making it available to the masses as inexpensively as possible. Traditionally associated with a strong community so vital to the creation and distribution of craft, crafting has since lost its use-value and has been "captured by capital".<ref>{{harvnb|Bratich|2006|p=25}}</ref>
A popular way to resist the commoditization of craft is through the Do-It-Yourself or DIY movement. Popularized through "zines" of the 1990s, DIY inspires people to be self-sufficient and to rely less on the market for basic necessities that can easily be created on one's own. DIY is a resistance to both the capitalist nature of the fashion industry and pressures to conform and buy a style.<ref>{{cite news |last=Higgins |first= Charlotte |date=January 31, 2005 |title=Political protest turns to the radical art of knitting |work= The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/jan/31/arts.artsnews1 |accessdate=2 November 2012 |location=London}}</ref> An example of this is the Counterfeit Crochet Project, which seeks to "debase and defile designer items one step at a time".<ref group="note">Counterfeit Crochet Project by Stephanie Syjuco http://www.counterfeitcrochet.org/</ref> Crafters have also subverted the market through the use of open source patterns and information sharing on the internet. Sites like [[Burdastyle]] allow crafters to upload and download sewing projects at no charge.<ref>http://www.burdastyle.com</ref> Similarly, Cat Mazza's online software [[KnitPro]]<ref>http://www.microrevolt.org/knitPro.htm</ref> allows users to download images into detailed knitting patterns at no charge.
====Anti-sweatshop==== Efforts within the craftivist movement against capitalism focus primarily on the international issue of [[sweatshops]]. Some craftivists believe that either sewing one's own clothing or buying only hand-made is the best way to protest unfair labor practices around the globe. Other craftivists take the issue even further, using the act of crafting as a protest against sweatshops. Artist and activist [[Cat Mazza]] created a campaign against the inhumane labor practices of [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] through the creation of a giant blanket depicting Nike's trademark swoosh. From 2003-2008, international crafters were asked to mail in 4x4 inch stitched squares to border the blanket and to sign a petition against Nike.<ref>Microrevolt Blanket. http://www.microrevolt.org/web/blanket.htm April 10, 2009</ref> Mazza also created a second web-based software called [[Knitoscope]] that transforms video into animated knitted stitches.<ref name="turbulence.org">http://www.turbulence.org/Works/microRevolt/testimonies.html</ref> Each video has a corresponding testimony featuring various professionals who work against sweatshop labor.<ref name="turbulence.org"/>
Artist and Activist Kirsty Robertson feels that the subversive efforts of craftivists against capitalism are limited by their dependency on the internet and new communication. She points out that for this reason, global justice knitters are not completely removed from the economy themselves <ref name="Robertson, Kirsty 2006"/>
===Anti-war=== Some craftivists see their art form as a protest against war and violence. Anti-war craftivists choose to make their statement by juxtaposing a colorful, soft, and fuzzy yarn with cold and dangerous weapons. In 2006, Danish artist Marianne Jorgensen stitched a giant pink "tank blanket" and placed it over a M24 Chafee combat tank to protest the Iraq war.<ref name="marianneart.dk">Pink M.24 Chafee. http://www.marianneart.dk/ April 10, 2009</ref> She has been making these blankets since Denmark entered the Iraq War, and doesn't plan to stop until it is over. She writes on her website that, "Unsimilar to a war, knitting signals home, care, closeness and time for reflection...When [the tank] is covered in pink, it becomes completely unarmed and it loses its authority".<ref name="marianneart.dk"/> Much like Jorgensen, Canadian artist [[Barb Hunt]] works to question the acceptance of military logic in society by creating knitted antipersonnel land mines out of wool.<ref name="Robertson, Kirsty 2006"/>
Similar to her campaign against Nike, Cat Mazza started an anti-war effort entitled "Stitch for Senate" on the fourth anniversary of the Iraq War. She enlisted two people from each state to knit a soldier's helmet liner which would be sent on to every senator. Unlike the apolitical Operation Home Front efforts that knitted gear for soldiers, Mazza wanted "to start a dialogue about the war and to get politicians to keep the promises they made during the midterm elections".<ref name="Gohil, Neha Singh 2007">Gohil, Neha Singh. March 13, 2007. Activists use knitting needles to make their point. Columbia News Service</ref>
The [[Viral Knitting Project]] is an anti-war effort that translates the 0/1 binary code of the dangerous Code Red computer virus into a knitting pattern of knit/purl.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kirstyrobertson.com/viral%20knitting/viral%20knitting.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713153258/http://www.kirstyrobertson.com/viral%20knitting/viral%20knitting.html |archivedate=2011-07-13 |df= }}</ref> The color and code relate to the anti-terrorism alerts of post 9/11 United States. The project is attempting to "draw together links between technology, culture, capitalism and war".<ref name="Robertson, Kirsty 2006"/>
===Social justice issues=== The Craftivist Collective, founded by Sarah Corbett, is an activist social enterprise which uses craftivism to engage people in social justice issues and solidarity movements.<ref name="ohcomely">Charlotte Humphery, ''We'll change the world stitch by stitch'', ''Oh Comely'' magazine</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.etsy.com/au/listing/158988814/resistance|title=Resistance by Crafterdark|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> There is a manifesto and a checklist of goals for the work of the group which includes being welcoming,<ref name="satreview">Ruth Lewy, ''I get frustrated knitting socks. I want to make a difference.'', ''The Times Saturday Review'', 10 December 2011</ref> encouraging and positive,<ref name="positive2">Rin Simpson, ''Getting crafty: a creative approach to activism'', ''Positive News'', Winter 2012</ref> creative and non-threatening,<ref name="house">Holly Howe, ''Sarah Corbett'', ''House'', Autumn 2010</ref> and focusing on global poverty and human rights injustices.<ref name="bigissuenorth">Jameela Oberman, ''Stitch in time'', ''Big Issue in the North'', 10–16 October 2011</ref>
One of the Craftivist Collective's key achievements was to convince the [[M&S]] board to pay their 50,000 employees the living wage in 2015.<ref>Alexi Duggins, [https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2017/sep/18/why-craftivists-are-hiding-notes-in-pockets-during-london-fashion-week ''Is there a protest message in your new jacket's pocket? You've been shop-dropped''], theguardian.com, 18 September 2017, retrieved 28 September 2017</ref>. This campaign was awarded with the Economic Justice Campaigner of the year 2017 by [[Sheila McKechnie Foundation]]<ref>[http://smk.org.uk/oxy_testimonial/sarah-corbett-craftivism-economic-justice-award-winner-2017/ ''Sarah Corbett, Craftivism, Economic Justice Award winner 2017''], smk.org.uk, 18 August 2017, retrieved 30 August 2018</ref>, and was nominated for the 2017 [[Care2]] UK Impact Award. <ref>[http://www.care2services.com/2017-uk-impact-award ''Vote now for the 2017 UK Impact Award finalists!''] care2services.com, retrieved 28 August 2018</ref>
On the back of this award, Sarah Corbett continues to work with large charities to deliver strategic craftivism projects and teach them in the art of gentle protest.<ref>Kirstie Brewer [https://www.bbc.com/news/stories-42181743 ''Why I leave hidden messages in High Street clothes''], bbc.com, 1 December 2017, retrieved 30 August 2018</ref>
=== Guerrilla Kindness === Australian artist Sayraphim Lothian uses craftivism to "make people's day brighter".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/christchurch-life/art-and-stage/9834934/Kakapo-sculptures-hidden-in-Christchurch |title=Kakapo sculptures hidden in Christchurch |website=Stuff.co.nz |date=17 March 2014 |author=Will Harve |accessdate=20 September 2016}}</ref> She leaves small handcrafted works of art on the streets for people to find and take home “aimed at creating tiny bubbles of joy in the lives of passersby, tiny surreal moments that might make people do a double take.".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/alannaokun/people-who-use-crafting-for-activism |title=10 People Who Use Crafting For Activism |website=buzzfeed.com |date=22 April 2014 |author=Alanna Okun |accessdate=20 September 2016}}</ref>
== Protest models == When craftivists take to the street, they utilize various protest models.
A popular form of protest is the "knit-in," where knitters infiltrate a public space and knit. They might ride a subway, occupy a civic building, or sit in a park. They use the knit-in to draw attention to their issue of concern. The [[Revolutionary Knitting Circle]] of Calgary, Canada stage a knit-in in front of Calgary's financial office buildings during the summit of the G-8 nations in 2002.<ref name="Gohil, Neha Singh 2007"/> The Knit-in not only provides an opportunity to protest against injustice, but also allows for a running discussion about social issues between the stationary knitters. Jack Bratich of [[Rutgers University]] argues that, "Knitting in public also creates a gendered question of space. It rips open the enclosure of the domestic space to public consumption, exposing productive work that has contributed to women's invisible and unpaid labor".<ref>{{harvnb|Bratich|2006|p=7}}</ref> Women are, thereby, able to gain power from an activity that previously symbolized their repression.
Craftivist [[Carrie Reichardt]] has covered her home, car and studio with mosaics which utilizes ceramics, screen-printing and transfers to highlight "plight of inmates on death row, the Black Panthers, and the spirituality of the planet."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/feb/07/homes |title=Interiors |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 February 2010 |author=Kate Makhail |accessdate=20 September 2016}}</ref>
Another form of craft-themed activism is guerilla art. The Texas-based group [[Knitta]] places street art such as street pole cozies and antenna warmers in cities throughout the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=Knitta homepage|url=http://www.knittaplease.com/Home.html|website=knittaplease.com|accessdate=20 September 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060306151047/http://www.knittaplease.com/Home.html|archivedate=6 March 2006}}</ref> Similarly, a blogger in England, Sarah Corbett, "creates textile art with political messages in public spaces first by herself at a blog called 'a lonely craftivist' and then as the head of the worldwide Craftivist Collective.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://alonelycraftivist.blogspot.com/ |title=a lonely craftivist |website=alonelycraftivist.blogspot.com |date=4 October 2009 |accessdate=20 September 2016}}</ref>
Volunteers for [[Postcards To Voters]] often create their own hand-decorated postcards to send to potential voters ahead of elections in hopes of increasing turnout. The work can be done solo, but is often done at "postcarding parties" at a volunteer's home or a cafe.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |title=Writing Postcards Brings Voters Back From the Edge: ‘It’s Sharpie Therapy’ |date=November 1, 2018 |last1=Tackett |first1=Michael |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/01/us/politics/postcards-democrats-midterm-elections.html}}</ref>
==In transition== In the spring of 2009, an online debate began over the definition of craftivism. The debate spread after the self-titled Craftivism team on [[Etsy]] had an inner-group argument about the political affiliation of its members, causing some members to leave the group. The original description of the group states, "The Etsy Craftivism Team is a team of progressive Etsyans who believe that craft and art can change the world. Some of us use our work to carry messages of protest and political activism. Others believe that the act of making craft can be an act of resistance. Still others see that by buying and selling directly from the maker we are challenging the all pervasive corporate culture that promotes profit over people."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://craftingagreenworld.com/2009/04/04/what-is-craftivism-division-over-the-definition-explodes-an-etsy-team/ |title=What is Craftivism? Division over the Definition Explodes an Etsy Team - Crafting a Green World |website=Craftingagreenworld.com |accessdate=20 September 2016}}</ref> Conservative members accused the group of assuming a liberal agenda, and argued that politics should not be involved. Some members of the group felt that the mere act of crafting itself was political, while others felt that the act must also be attached to a political message. Rayna Fahey from Radical Cross Stitch replied to a thread stating "Personally if a John McCain supporter joined this group and told me that my latest piece in support of indigenous sovereignty was a well-made piece that serves the purpose for which it was designed well, I'd think that was awesome and I'd have hope for the future of this world."<ref>{{cite web|title=Whose Craftivism?|url=http://radicalcrossstitch.com/2009/04/06/whose-craftivism/|website=radicalcrossstitch.com|accessdate=20 September 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090408031802/http://radicalcrossstitch.com/2009/04/06/whose-craftivism/|archivedate=8 April 2009|date=April 6, 2009}}</ref> In contrast, craftivist Betsy Greer believes that "the personal is political," and that you cannot separate the two.<ref>{{harvnb|Greer|2008|p=30}}</ref>
==Notes== <references group="note" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Bibliography == *{{cite journal |last=Bratich |first=Jack |year=2006|title=The Other World Wide Web: Popular Craft Culture, Tacticle media, and the Space of Gender |journal=Revision for Critical Studies in Media Communication |ref=harv}} * {{cite book | last=Greer |first=Betsy | title=Knitting for Good! | publisher=Trumpeter | year=2008 | isbn=978-1-59030-589-8|ref=harv}} * {{cite book | last=McFadden |first=David Revere | title=Radical Lace and Subversive Knitting | publisher=Antique Collector's Club | year=2007 | isbn=1-85149-568-1}} * {{cite book | last=Railla |first=Jean | title=Get Crafty | publisher=Random House | year=2004 | isbn=0-7679-1720-0|ref=harv}} * {{cite book | last=Spencer |first=Amy | title=DIY: The rise of lo-fi culture | publisher=Marion Boyars Publishers| year=2005 | isbn=978-0-7145-3105-2}}

[[File:Eassie Sculptured Stone 20090616 cross.jpg|thumb|right|Sculpted cross on the front of the stone]] The '''Eassie Stone''' is a Class II [[Pictish stone]] of about the mid 8th century AD in the [[village]] of [[Eassie]], [[Angus, Scotland]]. The stone was found in Eassie [[burn (topography)|burn]] in the late 18th century and now resides in a purpose-built perspex building in the ruined Eassie church. ==Location== The cross slab is housed in a purpose-built shelter with see-through walls within the roofless shell of the old Eassie parish church, {{gbmapping|NO35264745}} on the north side [[A94 road]] some {{convert|4|km|mi}} west of [[Glamis]] and {{convert|6|km|mi}} east of [[Meigle]].{{citation | title = Dundee and Montrose, Forfar and Arbroath | work = [[Ordnance Survey]] Landranger Map | edition = B2 | year = 2007 | isbn = 0-319-22980-7}} == Description == The stone is a cross-slab {{convert|2.04|m|ftin}} high and {{convert|1.02|m|ftin}} wide, tapering to {{convert|0.84|m|ftin}} at the top, and is {{convert|23|cm|in}} thick. The slab is carved on both faces in [[relief]] and, as it bears Pictish symbols, it falls into [[John Romilly Allen]] and Joseph Anderson's classification system as a class II stone.{{citation | last1 = Allen | first1 = J. Romilly | last2 = Anderson | first2= J. | year = 1903 | volume = 1 | pages = 218–219 | title = Early Christian Monuments of Scotland | publisher = Pinkfoot Press (1993 facsimile) | location = Balgavies, Angus}}{{citation | title = Preliminary list of sculptured stones older than A.D. 1100, with symbols and Celtic ornament, in Scotland | last = Allen | first = J. Romilly | journal = Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland | volume = 24 | pages = 510–525 | url = http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/PSAS_2002/pdf/vol_024/24_510_525.pdf | year = 1890 | accessdate = November 29, 2010}} The cross face bears a cross with circular rings in its angles, surrounding a circular central boss decorated with a keywork design.{{citation | title = Notes on celtic ornament - the key and spiral patterns | last = Allen | first = J. Romilly | journal = Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland | url = http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/PSAS_2002/pdf/vol_019/19_253_308.pdf | accessdate = December 2, 2010 | volume = 19 | pages = 253–308 | year = 1885}} The arms and shaft are decorated with a variety of complex interlaced [[Celtic knot|knotwork]] designs. The upper quadrants held a pair of angels, but have suffered some damage, the right-hand figure being almost completely lost. A similar four-winged angel can be found on the nearby Glamis 2 stone.These four winged angels are a peculiarity of Pictish stones and are not found elsewhere in Insular Celtic sculpture.
{{citation | title = On some points of resemblance between the art of the early sculptured stones of Scotland and of Ireland | last = Allen | first = J. Romilly | year = 1897 | journal = Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland | volume = 31 | pages = 309–332 | url = http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/PSAS_2002/pdf/vol_031/31_309_332.pdf | accessdate = December 2, 2010}} The lower left-hand quadrant shows a cloaked warrior armed with a small square [[buckler]] and spear, and the lower right-hand quadrant depicts a [[stag]] and hunting hounds.{{citation | title = The Pictish Symbol Stones of Scotland | publisher = Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historic Monuments of Scotland | last = Fraser | first = Iain | pages = 52–53 | location = Edinburgh | year = 2008}} The rear face of the slab bears a mixture of figural representations and Pictish symbols. At the top of the face is a damaged [[Pictish beast]] over a [[Double disc (Pictish symbol)|double disc and Z-rod]]. Below this is a trio of cloaked figures, and to the right is a figure standing in front of a potted tree, which historian Lloyd Laing has interpreted as having human heads suspended from its branches.{{citation | title = The Picts and the Scots | last = Laing | first = Lloyd | last2 = Laing | first2 = Jenny | publisher = Alan Sutton | location = Dover, NH | year = 1993 | page = 133}} Below this lie heavily weathered horseshoe and Pictish beast symbols. The bottom of the face holds representations of cattle that have suffered some weathering.{{citation | last = Ritchie | first = Anna | year = 1997 | title = Meigle Museum Pictish Carved Stones: The Official Souvenir Guide | publisher = [[Historic Scotland]] | isbn = 1-900168-27-8 | oclc = 51913539}} ==History== [[File:Eassie Stone back.JPG|thumb|right|Rear of stone, showing sculpted figures and symbols]] The cross-slab was found in the bed of the Eassie Burn, near Eassie Church by Rev. Cordiner, c. 1786. From there it was moved to the churchyard, {{cite book | last = Warden | first = A.J. | title = Angus of Forfarshire, the land and people, descriptive and historical. | year = 1880 | volume = 1 | publisher = Charles Alexander & Co. | location = Dundee | page = 25 | url = https://archive.org/details/angusorforfarshi01ward | accessdate = November 30, 2010 }} where it stood for over a century, until the 1960s when a purpose built building with viewing windows was built for it within the structure of the ruined church.{{citation | title = Site details for Eassie Old Church | work = Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Scotland, Canmore Database | url = http://canmore.rcahms.gov.uk/en/site/32092/details/eassie/ | accessdate = November 30, 2010}} The church itself was probably built in the 16th century on the site of an earlier building that was dedicated in 1246 by Bishop David of St Andrews. In 1309 it was granted to [[Newbattle Abbey]]. Although there are elements of the original, much of it seems to have been rebuilt in the late 1500s. In 1600 the parish of Eassie was combined with a neighbouring parish. The windows and doors were altered in the 18th century. In 1835 the two churches of the parish were replaced by a single larger one serving. Since then Eassie Old Parish Church has stood derelict.http://www.undiscoveredscotland.co.uk/glamis/eassiechurchstone/{{citation | title = Early Ecclesiastical Sites in Scotland: a Field Survey, Part II | last1 = Macdonald | first1 = A.D.S. | last2 = Laing | first2 = Lloyd R. | url = http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/PSAS_2002/pdf/vol_102/102_129_145.pdf | accessdate = December 1, 2010 | journal = Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland | volume = 102 | pages = 129–145 | year = 1969–70}} ==Relationship with other stones== The Eassie stone belongs to the Aberlemno School of Pictish sculpture as extended by Lloyd Laing from Ross Trench Jellicoe's original proposed list. In addition to the Eassie stone, stones in the Aberlemno School include [[Aberlemno Sculptured Stones#Aberlemno 2|Aberlemno 2]] (the Kirkyard Stone), [[Aberlemno Sculptured Stones#Aberlemno 3|Aberlemno 3]], Menmuir 1, Kirriemuir 1, [[Monifieth Sculptured Stones#Monifieth 2|Monifieth 2]], Rossie Priory, Glamis 1 and Glamis 2.{{citation | title = A missing figure on slab fragment no 2 from Monifieth, Angus, the a'Chill Cross, Canna, and some implications of the development of a variant form of the Virgin's hairsyle and dress in early medieval Scotland | last= Trench-Jellicoe | url = http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/PSAS_2002/pdf/vol_129/129_597_647.pdf | first = Ross | year = 1999 | journal = Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland | volume = 129 | pages = 597–647 | accessdate = November 29, 2010}}{{citation | title = The date and context of the Glamis, Angus, carved Pictish stones | last= Laing | url = http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/PSAS_2002/pdf/vol_131/131_223_239.pdf | first = Lloyd | year = 2001 | journal = Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland | volume = 131 | pages = 223–239 | accessdate = November 29, 2010}} ==See also== *[[Castleton, Angus|Castleton]] *[[Meigle Sculptured Stone Museum]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Commons category}} ==External links== *[http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=17730 C.Michael Hogan, ''Eassie Stone'', The Megalithic Portal] {{coord|56.61442|N|3.05661|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}} {{Pictish stones}} [[Category:Pictish stones in Angus]] [[Category:Pictish stones]]

'''Engineering design management''' is a knowledge area within [[engineering management]]. It represents the adaptation and application of customary management practices, with the intention of achieving a productive [[engineering design process]]. Engineering design management is primarily applied in the context of engineering design teams, whereby the activities, outputs and influences of design teams are planned, guided, monitored and controlled.
[[Category:Engineering]] [[Category:Design]] [[Category:Product development]]

[[File:Eugeniu Voinescu.jpg|thumb|185px|Eugeniu Voinescu
(date unknown)]] '''Eugeniu Voinescu''' (commonly '''Eugen'''; 26 May 1842, [[Iași]] – 6 May 1909, [[Bucharest]]) was a Romanian diplomat and painter, who specialized in maritime scenes. ==Biography== Following the wishes of his family, he originally studied law and literature. After spending some time studying in Athens, he went to Paris where he befriended the French artist, [[Gustave Courbet]], who stimulated his interest in painting directly from nature.[http://artindex.ro/2012/05/16/voinescu-eugen-cean/ Brief biography and paintings] @ ArtIndex. In 1869, he was awarded a prize at the [[Salon (Paris)|Salon]]. As a result of his legal studies, he also served as Romanian [[consul general]] in Budapest (1879), Istanbul (1882), and [[Odessa]] (1883-1888). While in Odessa, he became acquainted with [[Ivan Aivazovsky]], who helped him develop his interest in [[Marine art|marine painting]]. In 1889, he held his first major exhibition at a salon held in the new [[Romanian Athenaeum]]. Although he was lauded as Romania's best maritime artist by [[Nicolae Iorga]],[http://www.ziarulevenimentul.ro/stiri-2/Casa%20si%20gradina/eugeniu-voinescu-pictor--376715.html Biographical notes] @ Evenimentul. he also painted portraits and [[Genre art|genre]] works, as well as historical and biblical scenes. An important aspect of his career is that he was financially independent, so his painting always remained a hobby, even when he participated in decorating churches, such as the Cathedral of [[Saint Charalambos]] in [[Turnu Măgurele]] and the Church of Saint Nicholas in Bucharest. He was also one of the founders of the School of Decorative Arts at the [[Bucharest National University of Arts]]. In 2011, [[Poșta Română]] issued a series of four [[commemorative stamp]]s honoring Romanian artists, and one of Voinescu's paintings was chosen for the 2.10 [[Romanian Leu|Lei]] denomination.[http://romfilatelia.ro/marci/colectia.php?ContentID=547&Year=2011 Commemorative issue] @ Romfilatelia. ==Selected paintings==
File:Eugen Voinescu - Capul Caliacra pe furtuna.jpg|[[Kaliakra|Cape Caliacra]] During a Storm File:Eugen Voinescu - Copii vaslind pe laguna.jpg|Children Paddling on a Lagoon File:Eugen Voinescu - In voia valurilor.jpg|Adrift
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Eugen Voinescu|Eugeniu Voinescu}} * [http://www.arcadja.com/auctions/en/voinescu_eugen/artist/348561/ Arcadja Auctions: More works by Voinescu.] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Voinescu, Eugeniu}} [[Category:1842 births]] [[Category:1909 deaths]] [[Category:People from Iași]] [[Category:Marine art]] [[Category:Romanian diplomats]] [[Category:19th-century Romanian painters]]
